                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Our Faculty                                                                                                   Silver School faculty are creating knowledge for tomorrow and training the next generation of social workers. Our stellar faculty include a leader in qualitative research methods and the president of the National Association of Social Workers. Faculty members are shaping the discourse of the major theoretical and philosophical issues facing the profession, building a cadre of social workers in palliative and end-of-life care, and partnering with agencies and organizations to create effective interventions. LEARN MORE»                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Academics                                                                                                   The Silver School offers outstanding degree programs at the undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral levels. The Bachelor of Science program establishes the foundation graduates need to effectively address the social problems of today’s world. The MSW program offers an integrated curriculum, which weaves together classroom and field experiences, educating students about the pursuit of social justice. Our doctoral program prepares students for a successful career at an academic institution and for leadership roles in design and development of social welfare programs and policies.                                                                                                                                                     Student Manuals   The purpose of the Manuals is to acquaint you with the School's procedures and requirements so that you can succeed in your studies. Consult the School's web site and your email for updates.     Undergraduate Field Learning Manual (PDF)     MSW Student Manual (PDF) (includes Field Learning materials)     Fields of Practice and Focused Learning Opportunities (PDF)   Field Placement Process & Timeline Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)     Checklist Field Placement Process Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)   Informational Meetings - Focused Learning Opportunities and Fields of Practice (PDF)     Student Field Placement Web Forms   Login with your University ‘Albert’ NetID and Password: Field Placement Web Forms     Your information on ‘Albert’ such as program, address, and contact information appears on the web forms and cannot be modified on the form. If required, please modify your information on ‘Albert’. These updates will automatically update our Field Learning database. For assistance please call the Office of Field Learning and Community Partnerships at (212) 998-5920.     Employment based field learning applications and guidelines:     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) / 900 Hours Application (PDF)     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) Guidelines (PDF     Employment based (Non-OYR) / 600 Hours Application (PDF)     Employment based (Non-OYR) Guidelines (PDF)       Student Evaluation Forms   The assessment of students in field is based upon the CSWE Core Competencies. The field instructor, in collaboration with the student, works to evaluate the student’s progress over the course of the year.   Initial Educational Statement   The Initial Educational Statement should be completed by the field instructor and student collaboratively. Part I, the Orientation and Field Instruction Plan, should be completed within the first two weeks of placement. Part II provides a baseline assessment of the student’s skill level, establishes the learning plan for the remainder of the semester, and provides an initial indication of the grade level of the student’s performance in the early stages of placement. Part II should be completed in the 7th week of field placement.     Undergraduate Senior Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Professional Foundation Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement / Micro Macro Practice (PDF)     Mid-Year Evaluation   The Mid-Year Evaluation is completed at the end of the first semester of either the foundation year or the advanced concentration year and after the student has finished the 300 hours required for field instruction. The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the evaluation as a major component of assigning a grade for Field Instruction. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation).   Final Evaluation   This evaluation is completed at the end of the second semester of either the foundation or advanced concentration placement, after the student has finished the additional 300 hours required for Field Instruction (and a total of 600 hours for each of the foundation and advanced concentration placements). The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the Final Evaluation as a major component of the process of assigning a grade for Field Instruction II or IV. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation.)     MSW Professional Foundation Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)   MSW Advanced Concentration Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)     Undergraduate Senior Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)   Undergraduate Junior Final Evaluation (PDF) (After completion of 100 hours)       Form Instructions: Save a copy of the PDF form(s) to your computer prior to completing the evaluation form. The field instructor and student should both sign the evaluation form. The evaluation can be scanned and emailed to field.learning@nyu.edu or and faxed to (212) 995-4533.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Our Faculty                                                                                                   Silver School faculty are creating knowledge for tomorrow and training the next generation of social workers. Our stellar faculty include a leader in qualitative research methods and the president of the National Association of Social Workers. Faculty members are shaping the discourse of the major theoretical and philosophical issues facing the profession, building a cadre of social workers in palliative and end-of-life care, and partnering with agencies and organizations to create effective interventions. LEARN MORE»                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Academics                                                                                                   The Silver School offers outstanding degree programs at the undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral levels. The Bachelor of Science program establishes the foundation graduates need to effectively address the social problems of today’s world. The MSW program offers an integrated curriculum, which weaves together classroom and field experiences, educating students about the pursuit of social justice. Our doctoral program prepares students for a successful career at an academic institution and for leadership roles in design and development of social welfare programs and policies.                                                                                                                                                     Student Manuals   The purpose of the Manuals is to acquaint you with the School's procedures and requirements so that you can succeed in your studies. Consult the School's web site and your email for updates.     Undergraduate Field Learning Manual (PDF)     MSW Student Manual (PDF) (includes Field Learning materials)     Fields of Practice and Focused Learning Opportunities (PDF)   Field Placement Process & Timeline Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)     Checklist Field Placement Process Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)   Informational Meetings - Focused Learning Opportunities and Fields of Practice (PDF)     Student Field Placement Web Forms   Login with your University ‘Albert’ NetID and Password: Field Placement Web Forms     Your information on ‘Albert’ such as program, address, and contact information appears on the web forms and cannot be modified on the form. If required, please modify your information on ‘Albert’. These updates will automatically update our Field Learning database. For assistance please call the Office of Field Learning and Community Partnerships at (212) 998-5920.     Employment based field learning applications and guidelines:     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) / 900 Hours Application (PDF)     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) Guidelines (PDF     Employment based (Non-OYR) / 600 Hours Application (PDF)     Employment based (Non-OYR) Guidelines (PDF)       Student Evaluation Forms   The assessment of students in field is based upon the CSWE Core Competencies. The field instructor, in collaboration with the student, works to evaluate the student’s progress over the course of the year.   Initial Educational Statement   The Initial Educational Statement should be completed by the field instructor and student collaboratively. Part I, the Orientation and Field Instruction Plan, should be completed within the first two weeks of placement. Part II provides a baseline assessment of the student’s skill level, establishes the learning plan for the remainder of the semester, and provides an initial indication of the grade level of the student’s performance in the early stages of placement. Part II should be completed in the 7th week of field placement.     Undergraduate Senior Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Professional Foundation Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement / Micro Macro Practice (PDF)     Mid-Year Evaluation   The Mid-Year Evaluation is completed at the end of the first semester of either the foundation year or the advanced concentration year and after the student has finished the 300 hours required for field instruction. The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the evaluation as a major component of assigning a grade for Field Instruction. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation).   Final Evaluation   This evaluation is completed at the end of the second semester of either the foundation or advanced concentration placement, after the student has finished the additional 300 hours required for Field Instruction (and a total of 600 hours for each of the foundation and advanced concentration placements). The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the Final Evaluation as a major component of the process of assigning a grade for Field Instruction II or IV. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation.) The field instructor and student should both sign the evaluation form. The evaluation can be scanned and emailed to field.learning@nyu.edu or and faxed to (212) 995-4533.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          The Silver School of Social Work provides a rich environment for the education of professional social workers—offering undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral degrees—with a curriculum that reflects current knowledge from both research and practice. With a commitment to social justice, an emphasis on research, and a long history of excellent clinical training, the School provides a strong education for the next generation of social workers. A Silver School degree will go beyond the essentials of social work eduction—it offers an extensive array of advanced and elective courses that deepens knowledge and training in one, or several, specialty areas. As part of NYU's Global Network University, the Silver School offers several global learning options to students in all degree programs. The School’s BS and MSW programs are fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education.     All MSW programs offered by the School are available on the main campus at Washington Square. In addition, we have two suburban campus sites—in Rockland and Westchester Counties—to make learning more accessible to MSW students living in the tri-state area. An MSW program at Shanghai and New York will start in fall 2015.                                                      Our Faculty                                                                                                   Silver School faculty are creating knowledge for tomorrow and training the next generation of social workers. Our stellar faculty include a leader in qualitative research methods and the president of the National Association of Social Workers. Faculty members are shaping the discourse of the major theoretical and philosophical issues facing the profession, building a cadre of social workers in palliative and end-of-life care, and partnering with agencies and organizations to create effective interventions. LEARN MORE»                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Academics                                                                                                   The Silver School offers outstanding degree programs at the undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral levels. The Bachelor of Science program establishes the foundation graduates need to effectively address the social problems of today’s world. The MSW program offers an integrated curriculum, which weaves together classroom and field experiences, educating students about the pursuit of social justice. Our doctoral program prepares students for a successful career at an academic institution and for leadership roles in design and development of social welfare programs and policies.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          The Silver School of Social Work provides a rich environment for the education of professional social workers—offering undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral degrees—with a curriculum that reflects current knowledge from both research and practice. With a commitment to social justice, an emphasis on research, and a long history of excellent clinical training, the School provides a strong education for the next generation of social workers. A Silver School degree will go beyond the essentials of social work eduction—it offers an extensive array of advanced and elective courses that deepens knowledge and training in one, or several, specialty areas. As part of NYU's Global Network University, the Silver School offers several global learning options to students in all degree programs. The School’s BS and MSW programs are fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education.     All MSW programs offered by the School are available on the main campus at Washington Square. In addition, we have two suburban campus sites—in Rockland and Westchester Counties—to make learning more accessible to MSW students living in the tri-state area. An MSW program at Shanghai and New York will start in fall 2015.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Our Faculty                                                                                                   Silver School faculty are creating knowledge for tomorrow and training the next generation of social workers. Our stellar faculty include a leader in qualitative research methods and the president of the National Association of Social Workers. Faculty members are shaping the discourse of the major theoretical and philosophical issues facing the profession, building a cadre of social workers in palliative and end-of-life care, and partnering with agencies and organizations to create effective interventions. LEARN MORE»                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Academics                                                                                                   The Silver School offers outstanding degree programs at the undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral levels. The Bachelor of Science program establishes the foundation graduates need to effectively address the social problems of today’s world. The MSW program offers an integrated curriculum, which weaves together classroom and field experiences, educating students about the pursuit of social justice. Our doctoral program prepares students for a successful career at an academic institution and for leadership roles in design and development of social welfare programs and policies.                                             Admissions Events                                                                                                                    Admissions                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The Silver School of Social Work provides a rich environment for the education of professional social workers—offering undergraduate, master’s, and doctoral degrees—with a curriculum that reflects current knowledge from both research and practice. With a commitment to social justice, an emphasis on research, and a long history of excellent clinical training, the School provides a strong education for the next generation of social workers. A Silver School degree will go beyond the essentials of social work eduction—it offers an extensive array of advanced and elective courses that deepens knowledge and training in one, or several, specialty areas. As part of NYU's Global Network University, the Silver School offers several global learning options to students in all degree programs. The School’s BS and MSW programs are fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education.     All MSW programs offered by the School are available on the main campus at Washington Square. In addition, we have two suburban campus sites—in Rockland and Westchester Counties—to make learning more accessible to MSW students living in the tri-state area. An MSW program at Shanghai and New York will start in fall 2015. Employment based field learning applications and guidelines:     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) / 900 Hours Application (PDF)     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) Guidelines (PDF     Employment based (Non-OYR) / 600 Hours Application (PDF)     Employment based (Non-OYR) Guidelines (PDF)       Student Evaluation Forms   The assessment of students in field is based upon the CSWE Core Competencies. The field instructor, in collaboration with the student, works to evaluate the student’s progress over the course of the year.   Initial Educational Statement   The Initial Educational Statement should be completed by the field instructor and student collaboratively. Part I, the Orientation and Field Instruction Plan, should be completed within the first two weeks of placement. Part II provides a baseline assessment of the student’s skill level, establishes the learning plan for the remainder of the semester, and provides an initial indication of the grade level of the student’s performance in the early stages of placement. Part II should be completed in the 7th week of field placement.     Undergraduate Senior Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Professional Foundation Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement / Micro Macro Practice (PDF)     Mid-Year Evaluation   The Mid-Year Evaluation is completed at the end of the first semester of either the foundation year or the advanced concentration year and after the student has finished the 300 hours required for field instruction. The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the evaluation as a major component of assigning a grade for Field Instruction. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation).   Final Evaluation   This evaluation is completed at the end of the second semester of either the foundation or advanced concentration placement, after the student has finished the additional 300 hours required for Field Instruction (and a total of 600 hours for each of the foundation and advanced concentration placements). The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the Final Evaluation as a major component of the process of assigning a grade for Field Instruction II or IV. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation.)
